ygData.subject: Re: Trouble running Fortran - Cantera interface
ygData.msgSnippet: It looks to me like you need to change some of the default settings of the Fortran project. Cantera is configured to use C-style argument passing, and the

Subject: Re: Trouble running Fortran - Cantera interface

It looks to me like you need to change some of the default settings of the Fortran project. 
Cantera is configured to use C-style argument passing, and the appropriate options need 
to be selected for the Fortran project.  Also, set the compiler option to generate 
lowercase names with a trailing underscore (like unix Fortran compilers do).  And finally, 
link to the multithreaded DLL C libraries.  Without an Intel Fortran compiler myself, it is 
hard to provide more detailed help, but hopefully this will take care of the problem. 


--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "killakella2000" <ryankel@h...> wrote:
> I thought I would repost this because I am still in need of some 
> help.  I am still at the same point in trying to link the Fortran 
> project to the C++ project.  Obviously, based on all the errors 
> listed below, things are not being passed correctly between the two 
> projects.  I would really appreciate any comments that might point 
> me in the right direction for fixing these errors and getting the 
> fortran-C++ interface to work with Cantera.  Thank you.
> 
> 
> 
> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> > I don't have Intel Fortran, so I'm not going to be able to help 
> much

> > > --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> 
> wrote:
> > >> It would be easiest to use a Fortran compiler that is compatible
> > > with
> > >> Visual Studio .NET.  I think the Intel Fortran compiler is.  
> Since
> > > I
> > >> hardly ever use a PC anymore, perhaps someone else can better
> > > answer
> > >> this question.
> > >>
> > >> The f77 and f90 demo programs can all be built very easily on
> > > systems
> > >> that support the GNU tools (make, autoconf, etc.) and compilers
> > > (g++,
> > >> g77).  In my opinion, anyone planning to do serious work in
> > > Fortran (or
> > >> C++) with Cantera should at least consider getting a machine 
> that
> > > runs
> > >> some unix-like operating system, such as linux or Mac OS X.  You
> > > can
> > >> get one for less than $1K, and don't need to buy expensive
> > > commercial
> > >> compilers.  Just a thought...
> > >>
> > >> Dave G.
> > >>
> > >>
> > >> On May 26, 2005, at 2:01 PM, killakella2000 wrote:
> > >>

> > > built
> > >>> and installed Cantera from the source code using Visual

> > >>> etc) could not be located.  I fixed this by changing the paths 
> to
> > >>> the header files in the demo_ftnlib.cpp file to

> > >>> C++ .NET?

> > >>> demo_ftnlib.cpp and run the included makefile to link that .obj
> > > file
